title: How to Clean Curtains

steps.headline: Take your curtains off of the rod if you can and take them outside.
steps.description: If your curtain rod doesn’t require any power tools to remove, take your rod apart and take your curtains outside. If you can’t remove your curtains because it would involve getting a drill out, you can simply put a drop cloth underneath your curtains to keep dust from falling on to the floor.

steps.headline: Shake your curtains for 30-45 seconds to remove excess dust.
steps.description: Hold the curtains by the top of the fabric where the bar weaves through it. Hold your arms out away from you and close your eyes. Then, shake the curtains up and down in rapid movements to remove dust and debris. Keep your eyes closed while shaking it to keep the dust out of your eyes. If your curtains are still on the rod, hold them near the top and shake them lightly without pulling them away from the rod.

steps.headline: Turn your curtains over in your hand and shake them from the other end.
steps.description: Hold your curtains at the bottom of the fabric and repeat the process, shaking them for 30-45 seconds. Shake each end of your curtains multiple times in order to fully remove all of the dust. If your curtains are still on the rod, wrap the drop cloth inwards after you’re done and shake it out in an outdoor space to remove the dust from the drop cloth. Dust the room that the curtains are in after 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Vacuum your curtains using a hose with a soft brush attachment.
steps.description: Attach a soft brush attachment to the hose of your vacuum and turn it on to the highest setting. Hold the mouth of your hose and drag it down from the top of the curtains to the bottom until you’ve gone over the entire surface. Repeat the process on the backside of the curtains.Warning: Use the lowest setting on your device if you’re vacuuming sheer fabric, silk, or lace curtains.

steps.headline: Run the curtains through a no heat dryer for 5 minutes if you can’t shake or vacuum them.
steps.description: Remove your curtains from the rod, and place them in the dryer. Run the dryer on a no-heat, fluff setting for only 5 minutes. Immediately after removing the curtains, hang them up again to prevent wrinkling.

steps.headline: Use a duster to dislodge dust if other methods aren’t available.
steps.description: Counterintuitively, dusters aren’t as efficient at removing dust as a simple shake. However, if you can’t manage to reach the top of your curtains or don’t want to get dust all over your room, you can use a duster to clean your curtains. Starting at the top, hold the head of your duster against the curtains. Rotate the duster in your wrist to turn the head and collect dust. Move your duster downwards as you turn it until you’ve covered your entire curtain.

steps.headline: Spot clean small stains with dish soap and warm water.
steps.description: If your curtain can be washed, it can be spot cleaned with warm water and soap as well. In a small cup, mix a dash of dish soap with 1 cup (8.0  fl oz) of warm water in a bowl. Dampen a clean sponge in your soap and water and hold the curtain near the stain in your nondominant hand. Use the sponge to rub the stain lightly until it disappears. Rinse your sponge and blot the soap away by soaking it up. Let you curtain air dry after you’ve cleaned it with dish soap. You can also use a specialized upholstery cleaner if you have it instead of using dish soap and warm water.

steps.headline: Hand wash lace and sheer fabric curtains in warm water.
steps.description: Add a dollop of gentle laundry detergent to a bucket or sink filled with warm water. Place your curtains in the sink or bucket and massage each section of your curtains by hand. Hold a section of fabric and rub it between both hands before moving on to a different portion of the curtains. Air dry your curtains on a clothing line or over a shower rod. Read the tag on your curtains before washing them with laundry detergent. Some curtains will have specific washing instructions that will prohibit certain soaps.

steps.headline: Throw standard fabric curtains in the washer.
steps.description: Thicker cotton, polyester, or blended curtains can be washed in a washing machine using your standard laundry detergent. Set your washing machine to its lowest power setting, which is almost always “delicate cycle,” and use cold water. Treat your curtains gently, because sun-damage could make them fragile. Air dry them over a clothing line or shower rod until they’re a little damp. Never dry your curtains in the dryer. Hand wash your curtains if you’re worried about shrinking them.

steps.headline: Iron your curtains while they’re still damp.
steps.description: After they’ve air dried for an hour or so, take your curtains down while they’re still a little damp. Spread your curtains out so that the length lays flat across the top of your ironing board. Turn your iron to low heat and iron them by moving the iron downwards towards the bottom of your curtains.Tip: If they leave moisture on your hand when you touch them, they’re still too wet. Let them air dry for another 15-30 minutes before ironing them. Curtains stay noticeably wrinkled if you wash them. Ironing your curtains while they’re still damp will keep the fabric even and uniform.

steps.headline: Dry clean formal or linen curtains.
steps.description: If you have any delicate linen or lace curtains, you may need to get them dry cleaned if you want them thoroughly cleaned. Read the tag on your curtains to see if it says “dry clean only” or “don’t wash.” If it does, take them to your local dry cleaner to get them thoroughly washed.

steps.headline: Check the tag on your curtains before steam cleaning them.
steps.description: If it says that the curtains can only be dry cleaned, you shouldn't steam clean them. Otherwise, you could damage them. Most fabric curtains can be steam cleaned.

steps.headline: Fill a steamer with water.
steps.description: Fill your steamer with tap water and turn it on the lowest heat setting. If you use high heat, you’ll risk damaging your curtains or causing discoloration.Warning: You cannot steam silk curtains, or you will damage them permanently. Use a dry steam cleaner if you have one. While they’re more expensive, they boil the water before emitting steam, which makes the drying process easier. You can purchase a steamer at a local cleaning supply or department store.

steps.headline: Start by spot-testing a small area with your steamer.
steps.description: Rather than leaping right into steaming your whole curtain, test a small area in an inconspicuous place first. Wait for the spot to dry completely and check for discoloration. If the curtain looks fine, you can move on to steaming your entire curtain.

steps.headline: Work your way from the top of your curtains downwards.
steps.description: Place the hose or mouth of your steamer at the very top of your curtains, 2–4 inches (5.1–10.2 cm) away from the fabric. Steady the hose or mouth of your steamer with both hands and pull the trigger to steam your curtains. Move the hose or mouth horizontally while moving your device down towards the ground. Don’t press the mouth of your handheld steamer or hose directly into your fabric. If your curtains start to get wet, hold your steamer further away from the curtains.

steps.headline: Stand on the opposite side of your curtains and repeat the process.
steps.description: Hold the steamer against the opposite side of your curtains. Steam the opposite side using the same settings. Keep the steamer away from the fabric at the same distance that you did on the previous side.
